title.narrative: Strategic Partnership Lobbying en Advocacy Programme Vietnam

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Human Rights are effectively enforced and aligned with international norms by governments, ILO and UN (Protect and Remedy) Outcome 2: Civil Society Organisations (trade unions and NGOs) have become more effective actors and have strengthened their role in Human Rights Protection and Remedy actions in the RMG sector. (Protect, Respect and Remedy). More specifically, Trade unions and NGOs will be more effective participants in human rights protection through increased capacity for lobby and advocacy. Outcome 3: Actions of companies (brands and factories) in the RMG sector actively and effectively support and implement Human Rights at the company level. (Respect and Remedy)
Payment of living wages Social dialogue as standard industry behaviour Elimination of gender-based violence and discrimination at work

title.narrative: Inclusive labour rights

description.narrative: Inclusive Labour rights, laws and policies are respected, promoted and adquately practiced.

title.narrative: # of (inter)national policies on SP issues implemented in accordance with standards or requirements

description.narrative: # of new/updated/ improved labour policies and laws on SP issues are adequately practised upon

comment.narrative:
No results achieved in Q1 and Q2 and Q3.. But there are key points/progress/challenge of this indicator so far have been transpired during Q1 of 2019: (1). In Vietnam, we are working towards implementation of effective social dialogue at workplace. A taskforce with participation of trade union representatives and management representatives of 7 companies were set up to conduct dialogue at workplace and hopefully reach an agreement to conclude a MC-CBA. At the time of reporting, the taskforce included 50% of production workers which shows 20% increase in production workers than previous quarter.
Q2: "No target achieved in Q2. But there are key points/progress/challenge of this indicator so far have been transpired during Q2 of 2019:
(1). Five garment companies in Van Lam district conducted effective social dialogue and agreed to sign an MC-CBA that would reflect the needs of both production workers and factory management. The 5 garment companies are: Ha Hung, Nhat Hoa, Y&I, Suntex and Viet Phat. (2). Vietnam ratified ILO Convention 98 in June 2019 showing strong committement on implementation of collective bargaining.
" Q4: "No target achieved in Q4. "

title.narrative: # of public or private sector institutions that implement (inter)national standards and policies to improve labour conditions

description.narrative: # of new/updated/ improved labour policies and laws on SP issues are adequately practised upon

comment.narrative:
No results achieved in Q1. This indicator is related to progress achievement on Indicator 1.1.1 above
Q4: "No target achieved in Q4. In total, 36 companies in 4 different regions including Thu Duc district and Tan Binh district of HCMC, Trang Bom district of Dong Nai province and Hung Yen city expressed interest in cooperation and work towards MC-CBAs in these regions."

title.narrative: # of mechanisms or processes put in place by the public or private sector institutions to ensure implementation of new or updated policies on SP issues

description.narrative: # of new/updated/ improved labour policies and laws on SP issues are adequately practised upon

title.narrative: # of mechanisms or processes put in place by the public or private sector institutions to ensure implementation of new or updated policies on SP issues

description.narrative: # of new/updated/ improved labour policies and laws on SP issues are adequately practised upon

comment.narrative:
No results achieved in the Q1 2019: This indicator is related to progress achievement on Indicator 1.1.1. & 1.1.2 above
Q4: "There is no progress update to Q4 for this indicator, but some progress had been made - followed up from the Q3 updated: The regional taskforce in Van Lam was established. They exchanged information on whether the MC-CBA is being implemented at their factories via social media. But face-to face meetings have not been organized for the taskforce to actually discuss on how to monitor how to monitor and evaluate the implementation of the MC-CBA. We have not been able to establish network of workers' representatives/strengthen grassroots trade union in order to get a good view of that happening in factories: how the MC-CBA is followed up, new suggestions and even case of complaints due to big workload. This activiy is planned for 2020. "

title.narrative: # of policies or laws formally adopted or blocked in favour of SP claims or issues

description.narrative: # of policies and laws on SP issues adopted/ blocked/ maintained that protect, respect or promote labour rights and improve labour conditions in the garments supply chain

comment.narrative:
No result achieved in Q1 and Q3.
Q2: New Labour Law contains elements on Social Dialogue and MC CBA.
Q4: "1) Labour Code of Viet Nam 2019 was adopted by the National Assembly on 20 November 2019 including provisions on social dialogue and multi-company collective bargaining. Article 73 of the Labour Code 2019 regulates that ""On the basis of mutual agreement, the parties involved in multi-employer collective bargaining shall have the right to request the provincial people's committee to establish a collective bargaining council for the purpose of conducting collective bargaining. The provincial people's committee shall be the one located where the enterprises involved in collective bargaining are headquartered, or selected by such enterprises in case where they are headquartered across multiple centrally-administered provinces and cities.""
Note: VGCL/CNVI has a contribution to the change of this policy: VGCL/CNVI lobby & advocacy work led to this policy change. MoLISA indicated in one meeting that they regulated the Collective Bargaining Council based on MC-CBA experiences in Hung Yen province.
"

title.narrative: # of improved or new policies on SP issues, claims and policy goals (at regional, national or subnational level)

description.narrative: # of policies and laws on SP issues adopted/ blocked/ maintained that protect, respect or promote labour rights and improve labour conditions in the garments supply chain

comment.narrative:
No result achieved in the Q1 2019: But there are key points/progress/challenge of this indicator so far have been transpired during 1st Quarter of 2019: (1). CNVI activities in Viet Nam focus more on grassroots, company and district level rather than lobbying efforts towrds policy making at national level.
Q2: "No Target Achievement until the Q2 2019: There are key points/progress/challenge of this indicator so far have been transpired during 2nd Quarter of 2019: (1). CNVI and FWF co-organized a high-level multi-stakeholders' mission to Vietnam to showcase the results of the SP in the areas of social dialogue, living wage and GBV to Dutch and Vietnamese stakeholders. "
Q3: 1 for SD - MCCBA Signed in Van Lam District: Five garment companies in Van Lam district signed an MC-CBA that reflects the needs of both production workers and factory management. The 5 garment companies are: Ha Hung, Nhat Hoa, Y&I, Suntex and Viet Phat.
July 14, 2019: MC-CBA signing ceremony: The MC-CBA of 5 garment companies in Van Lam District, Hung Yen has brought benefits to all the parties and hoped that the 5 companies will develop sustainably and inspired other companies in the garment sector in Hung Yen Province. The employers of the five companies signing the MC-CBA are happy due to more stable industrial relations. And the grassroots trade unions of the companies feel motivated because common working conditions for all 5 companies are created.
Q4: "1 new policies at national level: Article 72 of the Labour Code regulates processes of multi-company collective bargaining as follows: ""3. The representatives for collective bargaining at the sectoral level, multi-employer collective bargaining shall be determined by the parties involved in collective bargaining on a voluntary and negotiating basis. 4. The process of and approach to collective bargaining at the sector level, multi-employer collective bargaining shall be agreed upon by the concerned parties, including negotiation about forming a Collective Bargaining Council as stipulated in Article 73 of this Code.""
Note: CNVI have a contribution to the change of this new policy: this is the results of lobby & advocacy work of CNVI based on the MC-CBA pilots. MoLISA indicated in one meeting that they regulated the Collective Bargaining Council based on Hung Yen experiences. "

title.narrative: Increased capacities

description.narrative: Increased capacity to influence (L&A) on SP issues, claims and policy goals

title.narrative: # of advocates participating in capacity building (leadership development, trainings, etc) on SP policy-issues, claims or strategies

description.narrative: # of advocacy and policy champions promoting evidence base and influencing targeted policy and decision-makers

comment.narrative:
Q1 (54): SD training of trainers pool (representatives from VGCL, VCCI and Molisa) wrt MC CBA project
the 2nd SD training of trainers pool (representatives from VGCL, VCCI and Molisa) wrt MC CBA project
Q2 (25): (1). Training on MC-CBA for regional taskforce in Van Lam district TOTAL = 25 (M = 7 & F = 18 )
Q3 (19): (1). The 1st training of trainers (ToT) on social dialogue and collective bargaining in the South. TOTAL = 19 (M = 11 & F = 8 )
All participants showed great interest in the content of the training and understood social dialogue concepts. They also eagerly joined the role play with a case study. Mr. Sinh from Dong Nai Province FOL and Mr. Thai from Dong Nai Province DOLISA were very active with a lot of questions during the training. Ms. Giang from Da Nang City FOL and Mr. Thien from Thu Duc FOL did the homework very well and were assessed as good trainers. The candidate trainers must conduct 2 training on SD for colleagues or task force of each district or grassroots trade unions. The next training will be in November.
Q4: "Total = 67 (M = 41, F = 26) (1) Training workshop on social dialogue and CBA for Hung Yen province's trade union officers, 2 October 2019. TOTAL = 40 (M = 26 & F = 14 ) Questions from the participants focus on the limited role of grassroots trade union persons in CB. According to them, TU persons do not dare to negotiate with employers. It is difficult for GTU to represent workers in SD as they are paid by employers. Upon the completion of the training, the participants had a better understanding of SD model in the Netherlands and negotiation strategies for CBA conclusion. (2). The 2nd training of trainers (ToT) on social dialogue and collective bargaining in the South, 28-31 October 2019. TOTAL = 18 (M = 9 & F = 9 ) Upon the completion of the training, the candidate trainers had a much better understanding of different dialogue models through role-play exercise and obtained better skills in negotiation so that they can reach win-win results. (3). First Training for the task force in Tan Binh District, 21 December 2019. TOTAL = 9 (M = 6 & F = 3) The participants’ comment is that they need time for more understanding each other and more information exchange before coming to an MC-CBA. Mr. Ho explained that this is exactly what the project will happen. There will be more networking and training opportunities for the task force. All participants were happy to share their contact numbers with each other and look forwards to seeing each other again in the project. "

SD training of trainers pool (representatives from VGCL, VCCI and Molisa) wrt MC CBA project
the 2nd SD training of trainers pool (representatives from VGCL, VCCI and Molisa) wrt MC CBA project

title.narrative: # of mergings with other coalitions

description.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by partners and key stakeholders for, by or with their membership/constituency

comment.narrative: Q4: "2 merging with other coalitions: (1) CNVI become a member of Public Private Partnership in garment sector led by IDH: CNVI is contributed to the establishment of Domestic Advisory Group (EVFTA), the implementation of ILO Convention 98, cooperation with VGCL and MoLISA and regular meetings of the Public-Private Partnership group. IDH planned to organize the 7th regular meeting of the Race to the Top (RttT) program in November 2019 and asked for CNVI and FWF’s advice on the meeting content and agenda. RttT is a collaborative program being implemented under the framework of Public-Private Partnership Agreement to support sustainable development of textiles and footwear sectors in Vietnam signed on 27 Oct 2016 and extended till 31 Dec 2022 by the Ministry of Industry and Trade (MOIT), Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE), Ministry of Labor, Invalids and Social Affairs (MOLISA), Vietnam Textile and Apparel Association (VITAS), Vietnam Leather Footwear Association (LEFASO), Vietnam Cotton and Spinning Association (VCOSA), IDH and representatives from the Bands as Marks & Spencer and GAP. The objective of this agreement is to engage partners and the public and private sectors to work together to promote the sustainable, productive, social and environmental sustainability of Viet Nam's textile and footwear industry by implementing RttT program. The topic of the 7th meeting is Promoting the Sustainable world of work in the apparel and footwear sector in Vietnam after the ratification of EVFTA and ILO Convention 98 (2) CNVI participated in inter-ministry and NGOs network set up by MoLISA: This meeting is to prepare for the establishment of Domestic Advisory Group as required by EVFTA. MoLISA expects the need to have NGOs' contribution of fund and technical inputs for DAG establishment."

title.narrative: # of pilots

description.narrative: # of evidence produced by alliance partners in support of lobby and advocacy on SP issues, claims and policy goals

comment.narrative: 1 pilot for SD: (1). Social partners selected HCMC as the next region for the MC-CBA pilot project: • Meeting with HCMC tripartite stakeholders, including Ms Ha VGCL, HCMC FoL, TU representatives from 4 districts (Hoc Mon, D12, Thu Duc and Cu Chi), Florence from FWF, VCCI HCM, and TU Garment took place. • Project information was introduced to participants. Current challenges of the first pilot faced by Van Lam district were shared with them so that they can better understand the project steps.

No result achieved in Q1 and Q2 and Q3.
However, there is progress being made (1) Three more districts are examined to select the most suitable districts for the MC-CBA pilot implementation in HCMC including Thu Duc, Tan Binh and District 9 (2) Efforts are made to engage FWF suppliers in the MC-CBA pilot (see indicator 3 activity 6 and 9)
Q2: "No Target Achievement until the Q2 2019. However, there is progress being made: (1) Efforts are made to engage FWF suppliers in the MC-CBA pilot. At least 4 brands showed strong interest in the project. The 4 brands name are: Evolution, Vaude, Fond of Bags and Engelbert Strauss. "
Q4: "Progress up to date: (1) Fifteen garment companies in Hung Yen city agreed to cooperate and work towards a MC-CBA for this group of companies in Hung Yen city region. There is one FWF supplier in this group which is Hung Long II.
15 garment companies in Hung Yen City: 1. Hung Yen Garment Corporation: 2. Phu Khang Garment Limited Company, 3. Hung Yen Jute and Garment Joint Stock Company, 4. Duc Thang Joint Stock Company, 5. Hung Long II Garment Joint Stock Company, 6. Bao Hung Joint Stock Company, 7. Pho Hien Garment Limited Company, 8. Hien Nam Garment Limited Company, 9. Tien Hung Joint Stock Company, 10. Phu Hung Joint Stock Company, 11. Tien Lu Garment and Commerce Limited Company, 12. Thong Nhat Garment Joint Stock Company, 13. Huong Linh Production Commerce Limited Company, 14. Hai Trieu, 15. Garment 2"

comment.narrative: Manual on social dialogue has been developed

Q1 (3): 1. Manual for Social Dialogue in Vietnamese language 2. Leaflet for employers on MC-CBA 3. Leaflet for trade union/workers on MC-CBA
Q2 (1): 1). Information note on MC-CBA for brands
Q3 (3): Total 3 for Q3: 1) Flipbook on MC-CBA content 2) Leaflet on MC-CBA employers version (for HCMC) 3) Leaflet on MC-CBA workers version (for HCMC)
Note: (No.2 and No.3 above): The two leaflets were updated with HCMC stakeholders’ contacts to be used in Ho Chi Minh City. It is going to be printed and disseminated including one leaflet (No 1 above) explaining the benefits of MC-CBA for employers and one leaflet explaining the benefits of MC-CBA for trade union/workers. These leaflets will be used for the information-sharing meetings organized by VGCL and stakeholders in Ho Chi Minh City, training on SD for stakeholders in HCMC and the training for regional taskforce in Thu Duc District and Tan Binh District in HCMC. The digital flipbook on MC-CBA of 05 garment companies in Van Lam district was developed and circulated among regional taskforce and stakeholders. The flipbook looks professional and useful and is available to all workers.
Q4: "1) Website on collective bargaining in Vietnamese language: A website on social dialogue in Vietnamese language is being developed to share knowledge and materials on the topics with Vietnamese partners and stakeholders.
Note: The first version of the website will by finished by 15 Jan. the link will be copied later. "

title.narrative: # of partnering stakeholders / organisations / platforms delivering services or capacitating with SP to promote or strengthen evidence-base, issues, claims or policy goals

description.narrative: # of partnering stakeholders included by alliance

comment.narrative:
No result achieved in Q1 and Q2.
Q3 (1): 1). Exchange of best practice on MC CBA between CNV-I and the ILO in Vietnam.
ILO consultant is conducting research to document all MC-CBA efforts so far in Vietnam, with lessons learned and will organize a workshop with VGCL to discuss the research findings. ILO wanted to include social dialogue processes and the conclusion of the MC-CBA (ME-CBA) in Van Lam district in the ILO research. It is also equally important that the ILO is working with Vietnamese stakeholders to regulate unfair labour practices and workers' representative organizations to create conditions for effective collective bargaining to take place in Vietnam. The research findings will be a part of MoLISA’s Industrial Relations Report and VGCL report. The representative CNVI in Vietnam, Ms. Yen shared with ILO Consultant briefly about her comments related to the negotiation processes, role of stakeholders and support provided by CNV. At the end of October, ILO will organize a workshop to discuss the research findings and CNV will be invited.

Total 2 for SD: (1). FES (German NGO): Information sharing on labour condition and experiences of working with CSOs in Vietnam (2). International Labour Organization (ILO): Information sharing on trade union reform and experience sharing on social dialogue and collective bargaining

title.narrative: Increased engagement on issues and goals

description.narrative: Increased engagement of civil society, business and governments on SP advocacy issues, claims and policy goals

title.narrative: # of advocacy messages in political statements, policies, plans etc using SP evidence-base or addressing SP issues and claims

description.narrative: # of (re)presentations in policy dialogue on SP issues, claims or policy goals

comment.narrative:
No result achieved in Q1 and Q2.
Q3 (1): 1). New Labour Law contains elements on Social Dialogue and MC CBA.
End of July, CNV submitted a recommendation paper to VGCL, VCCI and MOLISA. It covered many topics, not only on Social dialogue CNV’s recommendations on the Labour Code revision were shared with VGCL, VCCI, VITAS and MoLISA. Ms.Yen got feedbacks from VGCL as follows: “VGCL is studying 22 pages of recommendations on Labour Code revision of CNV experts. Comments of the experts are very specific, detailed, referring to many international conventions and having supportive view of workers. Staff members in charge of industrial relations will absorb these ideas and provide comments for drafting team and editing team of the Labour Code from VGCL.” This means that VGCL really appreciates CNV recommendations. It hopes these changes will be reflected in the new version of the Labour Code draft.
Q4: "1). Provisions on SD and MC-CBA were included in Labour Law 2019 adopted on 20 November 2019. End of July, CNV submitted a recommendation paper to VGCL, VCCI, and MOLISA. It covered many topics, not only on Social dialogue. Mr. Hieu, Vice President of VGCL expressed appreciation towards CNV recommendations for Labour Code revision. There were some valuable recommendations that VGCL could incorporate in their proposal for Labour Code revision. Ms. Dung, Head of VGCL International Cooperation Department said that VGCL has 120 bilateral relations and 7 multi-lateral relations. Some trade union partners have been active in supporting VGCL in Vietnam for a long time such as LO Norway and LO Sweden. Among partners, only ILO and CNV are providing support for VGCL to implement pilots on MC-CBA. "
Stakeholder meeting: VGCL, employers, MoLISA, Dutch Embassy

title.narrative: # of dialogues, meetings, consultations, briefings, seminars, workshops, conferences, summits, etc held with policymakers, companies, influential decision-makers on SP issues, claims and policy goals

description.narrative: # of (re)presentations in policy dialogue on SP issues, claims or policy goals

comment.narrative:
Meetings with VGCL, VCCI and Molisa wrt MC CBA project
MoU (between VGCL, VCCI and CNV) was signed on 10 July with participation of tripartite partners (VGCL, VCCI, MoLISA), Dutch Embassy, business associations (VITAS, Hung Yen Bussiness and Association), international organizations and NGOs (ILO, FES, FWF…) and media.

Q1: 15 for SD: 1. Meeting with IR and Wage Bureau, Ministry of Labour, Invalids and Social Affairs to inform the Ministry on the MC-CBA pilot progress and introduce Asia coordinators to key stakeholders. 2. Meeting with Vietnam General Confederation of Labour (VGCL) to share the MC-CBA project updates and introduce Asia coordinators to key stakeholders. 3. Meeting with Van Lam District Federation of Labour to get updated information of MC-CBA pilot activities implemented in Van Lam and introduce Asia coordinators to key stakeholders. 4. Meeting with VCCI and VITAS to share the MC-CBA project updates and introduce Asia coordinators to key stakeholders 5. Meeting with FWF to get updated information on FWF lobbying activities in the area of GBV and living wage 6. Webinar with FWF brands sourcing from Vietnam to introduce MC-CBA pilot and convince brands to send suppliers to join the pilot. 7. Meeting with key stakeholders (provincial People's Committee, Federation of Labour, Provincial Business Association, DoLISA, Van Lam People's Committee, Van Lam District Trade Union and 7 participating companies) in Hung Yen to widely introduce the MC-CBA pilot project in the region. 8. Meeting with district trade union of Thu Duc district to see whether this district can be selected for pilot implementation. 9. Meeting with Evolution brand to see whether this brand can participate in the MC-CBA pilot. 10. Meeting with district trade union of Tan Binh district to see whether this district can be selected for pilot implementation. 11. Meeting with Van Lam trade union to discuss about pilot activities in Van Lam and identify the possibility of MC CBA 12. Meeting with Hung Yen provincial tripartite partners to strengthen the communication and support of provincial tripartite partners for Van Lam district. 13. Meeting with project advisory committee at national level (VGCL, VCCI, VITAS and MoLISA) to discuss the MC-CBA pilot progress and plan for next quarter. 14. Meeting with Dutch Embassy to share the project updates and better understand Dutch Prime Minister visit and trade mission programme. 15. Meeting with VGCL leader to share updated information on the MC-CBA progress and discuss about the orientation of trade union work, social dialogue and CB in context of ratified CP-TPP agreement and Labour Code revision.
Q2: 16 for Social Dialogue: 1). Meeting with VCGL leader to better understand the possibility of having independent trade union in Vietnam and possible ratification of the ILO C87 and C98. 2). MC-CBA factory visit - Ha Hung Garment Company to better understand the factory management towards the MC-CBA. 3). Lunch meeting with grassroots trade unionists to better understood working arrangements in garment sectors and issues that workers really cared for and what kinds of knowledge and skills that the workers gained from the MC-CBA pilot; 4). Textile sector meeting with Dutch Trade mission delegation: International Responsible Business conduct & SDG to share good practices such as MC-CBA project and Race to the Top programme. 5). Social dialogue seminar - exchange between TU and CNV on the Dutch model: Showcase MCCBA 6). GBV meeting with VGC to share with VGCL findings of FWF-Care International's GBV research and understand VGCL position on new ILO Convention on harassment and violence in the world of work. 7). Meeting to launch the MC-CBA pilot in HCMC to provide detailed information for stakeholders in HCMC including trade union, VCCI, VITAS, FWF, DOLISA on the project. 8). Meeting with VGCL team in HCMC to provide additional information for trade union team on the pilot implementation structure and ways to convince employers.. 9). Meeting with Van Lam district trade union to share experiences of MC-CBA projects in Indonesia. 10). Meeting with provincial project advisory committee to provide detailed update and gained the committee continued support for next steps. 11). Meeting with CNV trainers Ms Ngan and Mr Binh to explain their supporting role during the training workshop for regional taskforce. 12). Meeting with VGCL officers (Ms Ha and Mr Quang) regarding Van Lam progress and preparation for activities and HCMC. 13). Meeting with Vietnam Women Entrepreneurs Council, coordinator of DECP programme to identify potential trainers for HCMC. 14). Skype meeting with Rachel, Evolution to explain the MC-CBA processes and to see whether it is possible to work with one or two suppliers of Evolution on either a bottom-up single company collective bargaining or a MC-CBA collective bargaining 15). Skype meeting with Anika, Vaude to explain the MC-CBA processes and to see whether it is possible to work with one or two suppliers of Vaude on either a bottom-up single company collective bargaining or a MC-CBA collective bargaining. 16). Negotiation meeting with leaders of 5 garment companies in Van Lam district to conclude a MC-CBA.
1 for GBV: 1. Meeting between high level delegation (Cathelene Passchier and Jane Pillinger - GBV researcher), VGCL Women's Committee and CNV Internationaal on future cooperation on GBV, in the framework of ratification of the GBV convention by Vietnamese Government, Employers and Trade Union. "
Q3 (15): 15 for Social Dialogue: 1). Meeting with HCMC FOL about the implementation of pilot project in Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC): HCMC FOL's respond to the initiative was very positive. They are eager to start to implement the project and hope they can do much better than Van Lam District. 2). Meeting with IDH: Sibbe, senior programme manager of IDH said that he sees Public-Private platform in Vietnam as a good means for developing and disseminating communication materials around collective bargaining, as well as possibly grow programs currently supporting soft skill development and other supporting mechanisms. IDH is quite excited about this (MCCBA) and really keen to partner with CNV Int’ on this. 3). Meeting with Dr. Chang-Hee Lee, Director of ILO Country Office in Vietnam to share with the ILO results of the MC-CBA pilot in Van Lam district: Dr. Chang-Hee Lee mentioned that ILO will conduct a research to document all MC-CBA efforts so far in Vietnam with lessons learned and organize a workshop with VGCL to discuss the research findings. He wanted to include social dialogue processes and the conclusion of the MC-CBA (ME-CBA) in Van Lam district in the ILO research. 4). Meeting with Sai Gon 3 Garment Joint Stock Company: The company felt relaxed and expressed that they are happy to join after asking questions to clarify the benefits that the company can get from the pilot. 5). Meeting HCMC FOL: HCMC FOL, Thu Duc District FOL and Tan Binh District FOL showed their eagerness by having already approached the companies. Then they also nominated the participants of the first TOT to be conducted by Henk planned to be on August 19-21, 2019. Tan Binh District FOL invited Robin and Huyen to visit a company in the afternoon and Thu Duc District FOL invited us to visit 2 companies the next day to build trust with the companies and invite them to join the pilot. 6). Visiting G&GII Company: The company representatives are very open and said they are willing to join the pilot without any concerns about the challenges the pilot may bring such as the request to assign 3 people for the task force, granting workers to attend meetings and trainings. 7). Visiting Van Thanh Company: The owner is very interested in participating in our project. He doesn’t see any difficulties regarding the participation of production workers and time spending on training/meetings. 8). Visiting Thu Duc District FOL: Ms. Hien, Vice president of Thu Duc FoL was open to tell about the structure of her office and provide information about the district and the garment sector in the district. 9). Visiting Long Cuong Company with Ms. Hien and Mr. Thien from Thu Duc District FOL: Mr. Long - owner/ director of the company expressed his interest in participating in the project. And he can send production workers to join the trainings and meetings during the project. He hopes that the project can also bring him new clients from Europe. 10). Visiting INS with Florence from FWF: The company is upset because Hoc Mon was not selected as one pilot region for the MC-CBA. They would like to join the training with companies in Tan Binh because it is nearer to them. 11). Meeting with employers' representatives at VCCI-HCM Office: Mr. Nguyen Thanh Binh from VITAS in HCMC showed his interest in the project and willing to join the PAC. 12). Official review meeting of Van Lam pilot: Mr. Duong, President of Hung Yen Business Association became interested in having a MC‐CBA for his 15 enterprises (of which 10/11 in Hung Yen). 13). National PAC Meeting: Ms. Minh (VCCI) promised to talk with their local representatives to address the problem that they obviously feel ignored and uninformed. 14). Meeting with Ms. Ha, Deputy Director of Industrial Relations Department, VGCL Head Quarters: Ms. Ha was in a very good mood and very cooperative during our discussions related to the pilot in HCMC and the expansion of the pilot in Hung Yen province. 15). Meeting with HCMC PAC at HCMC FOL: HCMC FOL has made a list of people in the province/city level PAC and a list of trainers. Thu Duc District FOL and Tan Binh District FOL have made a clear list of companies which are willing to join the pilot and which other companies they are going to visit to invite to join. There was the presence of DOLISA of HCMC and VCCI-HMC. 15).
Q4: "25 for Social Dialogue: 1). Meeting with IDH and FWF: to exchange information on activities which were being implemented by three organizations in Vietnam and identified areas for collaboration. All three organizations expressed interest in contributing to the establishment of Domestic Advisory Group (EVFTA), the implementation of ILO Convention 98, cooperation with VGCL and MoLISA and regular meetings of Public Private Partnership group. 2). Meeting with the ILO: Ms. Andrea Prince, Chief Technical Advisor, NIRF Programme and Ms. Ta Thi Bich Lien, National Programme Coordinator, NIRF Programme: to exchange information on New Industrial Relations Framework Programme (NIRF). 3). Meeting with Dutch Embassy: to update Dutch Embassy of CNVI and SP activities in Vietnam and to get advices from the Embassy on the high-level visit of SER president in early 2020. 4). Working lunch with Viet Anh, FWF: to share about working schedule of Willem’s SD mission during the next days. Viet Anh updated recent and upcoming activities of FWF in Vietnam. 5). Meeting with FES: Axel FES Country Director, Tien, Vice Director and Thu, Project Coordinator: to exchange information about FES’ projects. 6). Meeting with VGCL: to introduce policies and plans of VGCL related to social dialogue, collective bargaining, and bottom-up trade union organizing; to update information on the timeline of Labour Code revision and how CNV recommendations have been incorporated. 7). Social Dialogue Seminar with National Assembly: to share experiences in social dialogue and collective bargaining in the Netherlands and possible lessons learned for Vietnam. 8). Meeting with HCMC Project Advisory Committee: to update the project implementation and share information about the high-level meetings in Hanoi. 9). Meeting with Thu Duc District FOL and the task force: to share about the project on social dialogue and in context with VGCL (national level) and Vietnam government, MoLISA and VCCI. Thu Duc FOL was proud to introduce the mission to the representatives of companies which are interested in participating in the pilot. They were happy to listen to Willem’s introduction about the project and meetings in Hanoi but not very open at the beginning with the questions about the workers’ real concerns. Eventually, they revealed some concern about the working conditions, stable job, income, social insurance payment, annual leave, or an annual tourism trip. 10). Meeting with Tan Binh District FOL and the task force: to share about the project on social dialogue and in context with VGCL (national level) and Vietnam government, MoLISA and VCCI. The meeting was almost the same as in Thu Duc District. The district FOL showed their commitment to implement the project but the people from the enterprises (task force members) were not very open at first and needed more questions to reveal the real concerns of workers. 11.) Visiting Johnson Wood- Tam Phuoc IZ, Road 3, Tam Phuoc Ward, Long Thanh, Dong Nai Province: to learn about the wood processing industry and introduce the SD project activities. The company was happy to receive the mission and learn about the pilot. 12). Lunch meeting with Paapa, Legal Officer of ITUC: to introduce the MC-CBA project, our cooperation with VGCL and Labour Code developments. 13). Meeting with Dong Nai FOL: to update the situation and discuss which district to focus for the pilot. In general, they showed high commitment to the pilot and had already done some primary steps with a list of 9 companies from Trang Bom District ready to join the pilot. 14). Visiting Royal G.M.T Co., Ltd. in Trang Bom District - one of the nine companies participating in the pilot - to know about the company and build more trust with the pilot. The Vice Director and TU President are open in sharing about the current situation of the company. They know about the pilot and are interested to join. 15). Meeting with HCMC PAC: to update the situation. Everyone was positive about the progress of the pilot. Mr. Vu- HCMC FOL updated the progress of the pilot. 16). Visit Tan Binh District FOL Office: to introduce project for garment companies, update on the project progress and share about their difficulties in operation due to shortage of staff. 17). Visiting Tan Minh Textile Sewing Trading Co., Ltd. in Tan Binh District: to get to know the company and build more trust. The young general director of the company is very open and interested in the pilot. The head office is in Tan Binh District, HCMC but all of their garment production factories are in Quang Nam Province. Therefore, it is not suitable for the company to join the pilot. Maybe, the company can join the pilot when the project is expanded to Quang Nam Province. After this meeting, the number of companies joined the pilot in Tan Binh is only 4. 18). Visiting Kafuna Co., Ltd. (Japanese owned) in Thu Duc District: to get to know the company and build more trust. This is the first-time they know about our pilot. Mr. Morino – the Director – is very friendly, but he says he will discuss again with his staff and confirm their participation later. Therefore, the number of 8 companies is uncertain and the task force training plan in mid- December may be not possible. 19). Meeting with HCM VITAS: to update the situation and build stronger relationship with them. They expressed her willingness to work with us and support more. 20). Meeting with VCCI-HCM: to update the situation and confirm their willingness to cooperate with us in the pilot. In brief, Ms. Bui Thi Ninh- Head of the Bureau for employers’ activities did not see the benefits for the employers - her members and VCCI-HCM still hesitated to make the decision to really participate. 21.) Meeting with Hung Yen Business Association: to confirm commitment of Mr. Duong – President of Hung Yen Business Association and discuss the possibility of project expansion in Hung Yen province. The meeting concluded that a kickoff meeting would be organized at the end of December 2019 to introduce the project and its benefits to general directors of 16 garment companies located in Hung Yen provinces and two districts nearby. 22). Meeting with Ms. Ha and Mr. Quang at VGCL head office in Hanoi: to update the PAC with the results of Robin’s visit to HCM and to discuss workplan for 2020. However, the PAC members from VCCI, VITAS and MoLISA could not participate in the meeting. On several occasions Ms. Ha stressed that our project is the most effective project they have done so far. 23). Meeting with Viet Anh, FWF: to update about the project results. 24). Meeting between Huyen, CNVI and Viet Anh, FWF: to update of the current situation of the project. 25). Meeting with garment companies in/around Hung Yen city: to introduce about CNV, project and idea of Mr. Duong of setting up network of garment companies in the region as well as the MC-CBA of 5 garment companies in Van Lam district signed in July 2019. In conclusion, the employers expressed interest and commitment to successfully organize the MC-CBA and other cooperation. The next step is to organize the 1st taskforce training for this group. "
